nodes.text: Rank-based intergenerational mobility in the United States has remained stable for children born from 1971 to 1993 (i.e., the US remains a land of opportunity in rank terms)
Rank-rank measures of mobility (correlation of parent and child income percentile ranks) show no secular trend across cohorts
Marginal income distributions widened substantially over time (income inequality increased among parents and children)

Data: linked administrative tax records covering children born 1971–1993 using SOI cross sections for 1971–1982 cohorts and population tax records for 1980–1993 cohorts; sample construction and coverage described

Measures: parent and child family income defined from tax records; mobility measured by rank-rank slope, log-log IGE, quintile transition matrices, and college attendance gradient (college attendance at age 19 via 1098-T)
Empirical finding: rank-rank slope for 1971–1974, 1975–1978, 1979–1982 cohorts approximately 0.30 with standard errors <0.01 (SOI sample, child age 29–30)
Consolidated series combining age 29–30 income, age 26 income (scaled), and college gradients is virtually flat for 1971–1993; OLS trend = -0.0006 per year (95% CI upper bound 0.0008)

Empirical finding: college attendance gradient (difference in college attendance rates between lowest- and highest-income parents) is essentially constant around 74.5% for 1984–1989 cohorts and falls slightly to 69.2% for 1993 cohort
Empirical finding: quintile transition probabilities (e.g., probability of reaching top quintile from bottom quintile) show little trend; e.g., 8.4% in 1971 and 9.0% in 1986 (child income at age 26)
Claim: There is large and persistent geographic variation in mobility across US areas (commuting zones/Census divisions)
Evidence: bottom-to-top quintile mobility ranges from about 4% in some Southeast areas to over 12% in Mountain states; regional rank-rank slopes and college gradients are stable but differ in level
Evidence: inequality measures (Gini, top 1 percent shares) increased significantly in the sample; increase in parent Gini for bottom 99 percent matches other surveys

Conclusion: Rank-based intergenerational mobility has remained stable, but increased inequality has magnified the economic consequences of the 'birth lottery' so that absolute income differences by parental rank are larger today
Limitation: inability to observe child earnings at age 30 beyond 1982 cohorts in the data, requiring use of age-26 income and college attendance as proxies and scaling to forecast age-30 mobility
Assumption / contextual claim: college attendance is a strong predictor of later earnings and the college-attendance gradient is a valid proxy for income mobility for younger cohorts

Context / contrast with prior work: despite rising inequality and predictions from the Great Gatsby curve and Krueger (2012) that persistence should increase, cross-area evidence suggests the correlation between mobility and extreme top-tail inequality is weak and stability is plausible
